posts.cooked:
Would you use an open-source signal client not maintained by Signal (android or desktop or etc)?

  • Yes
  • Never
  • Depends (discuss below)
0 voters

I see votes but no opinions yet, so here goes.

What considerations would sway you one way or the other?

posts.name: xav1er
posts.cooked: Signal Desktop is horrible, so I would love to use a different client that has lots of features, etc.

Yes I would, but Signals aggressive blocking makes this hard to do.

The desktop client uses Electron, which is not great. It bundles a security degraded and outdated version of the Chromium browser, which consumes a lot of RAM and makes this unsuited for mobile Linux, corebooted Chromebooks and any device with low memory.

image1201√ó243 51.9 KB

The lack of a web client in the browser makes this worse, on Element you can avoid Electron with that (not saying matrix is great, it really isnt).

On Linux there is Flare, written in Rust, really beautiful, but unusable as you cannot fill in the repetetive captchas. I get captchas sometimes daily, sometimes not at all, sometimes on every 3rd message I write or every new chat I open.

On the phone, I use Molly-FOSS, which is fine. It is essential if you have an Android Tablet and an Android Phone.

I would prefer faster updates though, previously I used Twinhelix‚Äô Signal-FOSS.

Having an entirely FOSS and reproducibly built Signal client is like number 1 priority. I am pretty sad that Signal doesnt manage to do this.

i was thinking do i answer ‚Äúyes‚Äù or ‚Äúdepends‚Äù, i decided to go with ‚Äúyes‚Äù.

reproducible builds are important though, that might lead to ‚Äúdepends‚Äù side.

but other hand, it is more important to have good protocol than having valid builds. so if protocol is good, alternative clients could exist. basically, if signal can dictate certain source code, it is more central power to signal organization.

this is good time to say this point:

if signal starts to use verified builds, meaning that certain builds can run. if it forces google play and apple app store, it is just plain bad, because it forces to use closed platforms. even if signal verifies builds by sideloading, it is still bad more or less, because it is more power to signal organization. it is like can users keep signal under control if something happens in signal organization.

posts.name: gongoscho
posts.cooked:
Twinhelix‚Äôs Signal-FOSS

A fork of Signal for Android with proprietary Google binary blobs removed. Uses OpenStreetMap for maps and a websocket server connection, instead of Google Maps and Firebase Cloud Messaging.

link_counts.title: GitHub - tw-hx/Signal-Android: Patches to Signal for Android removing dependencies on closed-source Google Mobile Services and Firebase libraries. In branches whose names include "-FOSS". Uses new "foss" or "gms" flavor dimension: build with "./gradlew as

posts.cooked:
I‚Äôd much rather use the official client, but I do also use Molly in order to have a second account.

hawk17:

Signals aggressive blocking makes it impossible.

What are you talking about? Signal doesn‚Äôt block anything.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
I already do. I trust the maker not to include backdoors because I am the maker myself.

Further I use (a modified) Molly on my tablet bacause I want the tablet as a linked device. I don‚Äôt understand why Signal not just copies that code.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

What are you talking about? Signal doesn‚Äôt block anything.

Given how illogical, wrong, or snooty most of the response is, It‚Äôs pretty generous of you to just focus on that particular portion.

thexav1er:

Signal Desktop is horrible, so I would love to use a different client that has lots of features, etc.

Going from an exaggeration to a vague whine of the desktop client‚Äôs so called impotence tells no one anything about what it is apparently lacking in comparison to‚Ä¶ whatever else you might have in mind.

It‚Äôs undeniably embarrassing that Signal Desktop still doesn‚Äôt have parity on GIF functionality. But I wish I had saved screenshots of when I first started using it because it is visibly smoother and cleaner these days. I remember when you could screw yourself over by just accidentally disabling the toolbar menu at the top via fatfinger double clicking. Had to do a complete clean out on top of a reinstall on the first day of trying it out.

As far as I am concerned, the official desktop client‚Äôs one big remaining embarrassment doesn‚Äôt take away from being incomparably less noisy and less maze-like to say Discord or infinitely less ‚Äútrying to make the late 90s meet 2010+‚Äù like TeamSpeak 5 is.

And to finish with:
I can‚Äôt help but note something that I have poked at before‚Ä¶ the Signal Protocol is trusted as basically self-evident and yet when topics like these pop up, the very same team and ethos maintaining it is revealed to be treated (by some) as ‚Äúsketchy‚Äù at worst or still treated with hesitance at best. But because some random person or group might slap together the most subjectively perfect, Attack on Titan-level ‚ÄúI am freer than you!‚Äù FOSS labeled alternative‚Ä¶ it should be trusted absolutely by default instead?

What‚Äôs the difference from just using encrypted DMs on FB or IG? You can trust it just about the same by default.

hawk17:

Flare, written in Rust

Thank you, I didn‚Äôt know this existed!

zetabeta:

reproducible builds are important though, that might lead to ‚Äúdepends‚Äù side.

Makes sense.

anon53652:

I already do. I trust the maker not to include backdoors because I am the maker myself.

Is it open-source? Just curious to see what implementations exist.

goodec:

Going from an exaggeration to a vague whine of the desktop client‚Äôs so called impotence tells no one anything about what it is apparently lacking in comparison to‚Ä¶ whatever else you might have in mind.

Hey c‚Äômon now, let‚Äôs keep the discussion friendly.

goodec:

And to finish with:
I can‚Äôt help but note something that I have poked at before‚Ä¶ the Signal Protocol is trusted as basically self-evident and yet when topics like these pop up, the very same team and ethos maintaining it is revealed to be treated (by some) as ‚Äúsketchy‚Äù at worst or still treated with hesitance at best. But because some random person or group might slap together the most subjectively perfect, Attack on Titan-level ‚ÄúI am freer than you!‚Äù FOSS labeled alternative‚Ä¶ it should be trusted absolutely by default instead?

If you don‚Äôt like third-party clients, be my guest. But the hostility seems unwarranted.

I am using a well known VPN (the only one that passes memory tagging tests on GrapheneOS‚Ä¶) and Molly-FOSS and Signal requires me to do captchas seemingly randomly.

sometimes every day, multiple times. Sometimes not for weeks.

This increases when I am added to spam groups, without even accepting them. And this increases when I am in groups where also spammers are.

This was so bad in the near past, that using Flare on Linux was nonfuncitonal. They even say that in their infos, that you shouldnt create chats, only write in exitsting ones.

Stop pretending this is not an issue‚Ä¶

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
nullptr:

Is it open-source? Just curious to see what implementations exist.

Of course, otherwise it would be a violation of the GPL license of Signal. If you mean if I also link to closed source libraries like Google maps znd fcm, then yes, I do. I‚Äôm no foss purist in these matters.

hawk17:

I am using a well known VPN (the only one that passes memory tagging tests on GrapheneOS‚Ä¶) and Molly-FOSS and Signal requires me to do captchas seemingly randomly

How is this related to third party Signal clients, which this topic is about?

anon53652:

Of course, otherwise it would be a violation of the GPL license of Signal.

Could you link to it? I‚Äôd love to take a look!

Herohtar:
hawk17:

I am using a well known VPN (the only one that passes memory tagging tests on GrapheneOS‚Ä¶) and Molly-FOSS and Signal requires me to do captchas seemingly randomly

How is this related to third party Signal clients, which this topic is about?

I think it was supposed to be a response to this:

Herohtar:

What are you talking about? Signal doesn‚Äôt block anything.

Signal seems to aggressively send capthas to non first-party clients, making them borderline unusable.

nullptr:

I think it was supposed to be a response to this:

Herohtar:

What are you talking about? Signal doesn‚Äôt block anything.

Signal seems to aggressively send capthas to non first-party clients, making them borderline unusable.

That‚Äôs definitely not true. I use both Signal and Molly and neither of them get CAPTCHAs. Plenty of other people on this forum use Molly and other custom Signal builds without issues. Signal doesn‚Äôt do anything to check whether you‚Äôre using a third-party client. The CAPTCHAs come from other factors, and mainly seem to pop up when people are using VPNs, likely due to the IP getting flagged for various reasons.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

mainly seem to pop up when people are using VPNs, likely due to the IP getting flagged for various reasons.

also, I‚Äôm pretty sure even then there‚Äôs some reputation system. I only had a captcha pop up on me once, when connected to a less-well known VPN, sending a message request to someone totally new. never had that before and never since.

hawk17:

I am using a well known VPN (the only one that passes memory tagging tests on GrapheneOS‚Ä¶) and Molly-FOSS and Signal requires me to do captchas seemingly randomly.

I assume you are referring to Mullvad. Try a different server from them. They have many.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
nullptr:

Could you link to it? I‚Äôd love to take a look!

github.com

GitHub - johanw666/Signal-Android: Fork from a private messenger for Android with...

Fork from a private messenger for Android with extra options added: full backup and (partial, ony text) xml backup of messages. Restore can happen at any time, not only after a fresh install. Import SMS database. Import of (unencrypted) WhatsApp databases. Removed apk expire. Choose between passphrase protection and the Android screenlock. Choice for the backup location (internal or removable storage on Android < 11 (on 11 and higher this is already possible)). Set the maptype in the place picker. Option to treat view-once media as normal media. Option to ignore remote deletion. Choose between FCM or websocket notification delivery.

posts.name: Tiwo Satriatama
posts.cooked:
nullptr:

Signal seems to aggressively send capthas to non first-party clients, making them borderline unusable.

I don‚Äôt think so. I had captcha loop with the official app a few days back. Switch to another network solved the issue.

Perhaps this question needs turning around? Reframing to ‚Äúwhat stops you from using the current Signal client exclusivley?‚Äù gets to some of the core.
For me, the one big issue is Android ‚Äòlinked devices‚Äô. I move between Android tablet and Android phone continually but Signal doesn‚Äôt serve my workflow
